Queen Elizabeth I was born on the 7th of September 1533 to King Henry VIII and his second wife Anne Boleyn (whom I’ve already written a herstory about). This loved, albeit unwanted daughter of the King reigned as queen of England from 1558 to her death on the 24th of March 1603 and is one of the most renowned monarchs in history.

During the greater part or European and global history, women have been seen as inferior to men, and still are to a certain extent. Therefore, Elizabeth I and her accomplishments were seen as an exception, not the rule, by the general mass. She had a female, fallible body and she herself was hence also fallible, partly as consequence of Europe being Christian and Eve, not Adam, bringing damnation upon humankind (Eve actually means “snake” in some Semitic languages). Elizabeth – who was third in the order of succession after her sickly younger brother Edward VI and her older sister who previously, just like Elizabeth, was declared bastard – was a strong-willed person, which will be discussed in a subsequent paragraph, and quite soon into her reign she announced that she was more than a ruler in name only, which not was expected because she, after all, was a woman. To still be able to rule with her “weak, female mind” she declared in several speeches, the first one in 1559 to the Parliament, that she had a separate political body, as well as a female one that would not interfere with political and royal concerns.

As any other sovereign in history, Elizabeth I had several advisors. The Privy Council was the British ruler’s main councillors and, of course, they were mostly comprised of the heads of the greatest houses in England, because if these were not represented in governing the country they might riot against the Queen. However, Elizabeth herself had the power to choose the members of the Privy Council, which she, in practise, had to elect in accordance with the men’s titles to avoid offending any of them, but she still removed some Catholic dissidents when she ascended the throne. With a diverse group of councillors, as they consisted of nobles all wanting the best for themselves, their final suggestions for her were, almost as a rule, ambivalent and she could thus easier take a stand against them without insulting the losing side too much, because it would have been outrageous if a woman, regardless of her title, would defy the great majority of the wiser men. The two most prominent men in the Privy Council were Sir William Cecil (whom Elizabeth called her “Spirit”) and Sir Francis Walsingham, both famously loyal to her and the Protestant Church. Walsingham is renowned for his intricate spy network, providing Elizabeth and Cecil with imperative information about foreign and national businesses before they made up their minds. Cecil was Elizabeth’s chief secretary and advisor ever since her coronation, making many final decisions for or together with her. Elizabeth also had the House of Lords and the House of Commons, the Parliament, which she however summoned very arbitrarily and then almost exclusively to plead for money, at least initially.

Young Elizabeth.

Elizabeth is renowned for having been a wise ruler. She received a rearing worthy of a prince, mainly done by Katherine “Kat” Ashley, whom Elizabeth had a very affectionate and motherly relationship with since the beheading of her real mother Anne Boleyn in 1536. Elizabeth would revere her mother long afterwards and in a painting in her adolescence she wore a necklace from her mother. Elizabeth never grudged her father for killing her mother. As you hopefully have read in my text about Anne Boleyn, Elizabeth was treated amiably by her parents, when they saw her, but, of course, she was not raised by them. Also, after Anne’s execution Elizabeth would be severely neglected by her father. Her governess sent letters to King Henry VIII writing how Elizabeth had out-grown her clothes since long and pleaded for the King to send some more.

Elizabeh’s education was eminent, making her fluent in seven languages, like English, Greek, Latin, French, Italian, Spanish, and Welsh, in addition to other ones which she did not master as well. She could also play many instruments, such as the lute, and was very fond of art and dancing. She received this excellent schooling, contributing to her sage reign, despite that she was declared a bastard in 1536 after Anne Boleyn’s death on May 21st 1536 and King Henry VIII’s expectations on his new wife Jane Seymour to birth a male heir. Elizabeth was reinstated in the order of succession after the Third Succession Act of 1543, but was removed again in 1549 during her younger brother Edward VI’s reign when he made his advisor’s daughter-in-law Jane Grey heir. The eldest Tudor child, Mary I, made a coup d’état and took over the throne after only nine days of Grey’s ruling in 1553. Elizabeth again became the heir after her half-sister “Bloody Mary’s” potential child, despite her being imprisoned in the Tower for her Protestant faith by her sister from March-May 1554. (“Bloody Mary” had 287 Protestants burnt at stake during her reign from 1553-1558, whereas Elizabeth gruesomeily had about 200 Catholics hanged, removed their entrails, and then beheaded – she had to be a fearsome Protestant because her right to reign depended on it; on February 25th, for example, Elizabeth was excommuted by Pope Pius V).

Elizabeth is infamous for her dominant and sometimes aggressive behaviour. She broke her court lady Mary Scudamore’s finger after she had married without Elizabeth’s permission. Moreover, Elizabeth demanded absolute presence from her court ladies, with exceptions for grave illnesses and they had to spend as much time during and after a pregnancy as possible at her side. She was at other times very amiable and watched over her favourites’ beds during times of sickness and sorrow.

The only wife that King Henry VIII did not rid himself of, Catherine Parr, took Elizabeth under her wing after Henry’s death in 1547. Parr’s new husband Thomas Seymour who earlier had been an ardent proposer of Elizabeth is notorious for having molested her. Rumours even spread about him making her pregnant, which tried to be covered up by the court.

Elizabeth loved sugar and even sprinkled it over her salads. This unhealthy habit, however, made her teeth repugnant and she had a few of them pulled out. The first time it was because she was so terribly afflicted by toothache, but still feared the pain of the procedure. To encourage the Queen, a man in her service volontarily had one of his teeth pulled out, just to show the harmlessness of it. During public appearances she would stuff her mouth with cloth and she avoided smiling as often as possible.

Elizabeth I was a well-known Protestant, but she still could not be considered to be the Supreme Governor of the Church, which the English sovereign was supposed to be instead of the Pope in accordance with her father’s Act of Supremacy from 1534. Through the Act of Supremacy of 1559 Elizabeth “merely” became the Head of the Church. Women at that time were not allowed to speak in a Church, only to be meek and modest and stay out of religious issues, and therefore it would have been absurd if the Church’s sovereign was to be a woman.

Despite being of the weaker gender, Elizabeth, shrewd as she was, made it to and advantage of hers. With England being one of few Protestant countries in Europe – Sweden, Denmark, North German and principalities, and Scotland in the 1560s – Elizabeth I was thought of as a royal bastard of the vast majority of the European royalty as, according to them, Henry VIII’s first marriage to Catherine of Aragon was never annulled. Still, a lot of these Catholic princes and kings were ardent proposers to Elizabeth, even though England at this time was a rather meagre country with a feeble army and navy and a poor treasury, but being in an alliance with England would still outweigh the disadvantages. King Philip II of Spain, for example, thought of it as his duty to liberate England from their heresy, Protestantism. It would also be in Spain’s favour to be in a marriage alliance with England due to the then existing menace posed by France, and it would be immensely unfortunate for him if Elizabeth instead chose to marry the king of France, which actually almost happened twice with Duke Francois of Anjou (whom she called her “Frog” as he had once given her earrings with frogs on them), but the Massacre of Saint Bartholomew’s Day in 1572 averted Elizabeth the first time and the second time she was truly considering it, but in the end thought of herself too old as she was 23 years old than Francis. Elizabeth would sometimes make it appear as she was interested in marrying, at times having marriage negotiations going on for a year, but always found some flaw and cancelled it in the “last minute”. However, she did at other times promise to marry when she would find a pertinent man, although she at other occasions explicitly said that she did not intend to marry unless God would change her will, thereby also justifying her virginity as if it was one of God’s choices. By refusing to marry Elizabeth created a cult around herself, renowned around Europe as the Virgin Queen or Gloriana, the Fairy Queen. She glorified the fact that she was a virgin and made it into one of her attributes.

Due to Elizabeth’s close relationship to Sir Robert Dudley (Elizabeth’s “Eyes”), and later other men, like the pirate Sir Walter Raleigh, she was around the country and the continent accused for having been “improper” with this man and even having married him. This scandalous saying was consolidated by that her mother Anne Boleyn was the “Great Whore”. This rumour was outrageous in Elizabeth’s, and her councillors’ and her peoples’, opinion, simply because of how unacceptable it would have been for in particular an unmarried queen to have done so. As Elizabeth grew older and her cohort more impatient even Robert Dudley, whom Elizabeth appointed to become the fine Lord of Leicester, would suffice as King, as long as she married. Moreover, it was during the 16th century believed that women had a biological need for sex and that their health would be unstable by remaining a virgin. Thus, the obsession with Elizabeth’s well-being increased even further with her not having sex, in addition to her heirless state, not ensuring the survival of the dynasty. Also, it was believed to have been a correlation, she both explicitly and implicitly expressed it in several speeches, between Elizabeth’s chastity and strong, untouched body and England’s strong, untouched, by enemies, land. Elizabeth tried to establish this belief during all of her reign, but it became commonly accepted when she reached the age around fifty. She was quite concerned with her health and took walks almost daily and also visited every great city in England during the twenty first summers of her reign. That her health also was quite tenuous in reality, not just as any woman’s was expected to be, made it more imperative for her to get married and reduce this virgin illness of hers – she was for example afflicted by smallpox in 1562 and endured regular migraines and fevers. Her make-up, with detrimental toxins like lead and mercury, used excessively in particular after having reached menopause, contributed to her poor health. During Elizabeth’s last years 2 hours were required in the morning to apply make-up to the Queen and dress her. Elizabeth used an abundance of make-up to consolidate the cult around her virginity, with very white skin, symbolising innocence, and red cheeks and lips to amplify her and her country’s health. To show her grandeur as queen he court-ladies were obliged to only wear black or white, as if to not outshine the Queen. At least 2000 gloves it is believed that she had (however, when possible Elizabeth wore simple dress, sometimes for a couple of days straight). Moreover, according to diplomatic visits at Elizabeth she was insecure and constantly demanded compliments. People saw an actual correlation between her virginity, her female gender, and her unpredictable health. Elizabeth, however, tried to make her virginity associated with strength and protection of God instead. A common illness by the people was believed to only be cured by a monarch’s touch and Elizabeth was usually more than happy to help her poor subjects.

Elizabeth never had children, although there have been some rumours opposing that idea, and she was succeeded by the only son of her cousin Mary, Queen of Scots, whom Elizabeth reluctantly beheaded for treason and killing her violent second husband. She supposedly only signed her death sentence due to the Parliament’s and Privy Council’s urging, as she made out a perilous threat to the English throne, but she had planned to make the verdict void and prevent the execution. Elizabeth’s, and her cousin Mary’s, heir, declared in March 1603 (although, Cecil had a correspondance with him from early 1601), took the name James I as the king of Britain and Scotland when he was made King on March 24th 1603. His first years of reigning were turbulent as he opposed the Parliament and had difficulties relating to his people, along with a very pompous spending, which on the other hand Elizabeth also had and the royal treasury was, however, almost empty when James came to power.

Elizabeth I is known to the modern great mass for having defeated the Spanish Armada in 1588. Anything related to the military was a man’s business. The English victory was not exclusively due to swift English ships, but also because of storms and heavy winds, shattering the Spanish fleets. Moreover, the initial eminent commander of the Spanish fleet died a few weeks before the attack was launched and his replacement was a seasick man with insufficient knowledge about naval warfare. The final stage for the Catholic Spain attacking England was due to the execution of the Catholic Mary Queen of Scots in 1587 after several plots to remove her cousin Elizabeth from the throne. In that sense, Elizabeth elicited a Spanish invasion. Just before the attack she held a famous speech for the troops at Tilbury, England, where she had appointed her previously – he had married one of her court ladies without her consent – very dear Sir Robert Dudley to command. There, Elizabeth gave a speech to rally the troops and made a correlation between how she had been “unpenetrated” and how her country would remain that way as well. She was soon transported to safety, pertinently for a woman, in contrast to her male ancestors who all lead troops with or without success. Elizabeth funded, through the royal treasury, preparations before the Invasion thanks to the information regarding it from Sir Walsingham’s spy network. In 1587 Elizabeth sent Sir Francis Drake to the Spanish harbour in Cadiz to loot and demolish as many ships as possible. This act postponed the Spanish Invasion until July 1588, thus buying some time for the English to prepare. Elizabeth was also involved in the Dutch Revolt, which begun in 1568. After the assassination in of the Dutch revolutionary leader William I of Orange, Robert Dudley with troops was sent over to the Netherlands, albeit with little success. The British started sending more troops over there after the Treaty of Nonsuch of 1585. Before that they merely aided the Protestant Dutch with money and land for stationing.
